method: {"ef_sec_hydrogen_orig_emi_co2_p_x2x": "literature value, emissions factors are applied here because they refer to emissions per unit hydrogen", "ef_sec_hydrogen_orig_emi_ch4_p_x2x": "literature value converted from kg/MJ to kg/t, emissions factors are applied here because they refer to emissions per unit hydrogen", "ef_sec_hydrogen_orig_emi_n2o_p_x2x": "literature value converted from mg/kWh to kg/t, emissions factors are applied here because they refer to emissions per unit hydrogen", "conversion_factor_sec_syngas_sr": "normalized to 1", "conversion_factor_sec_hydrogen_orig": "the molar ratio of the syngas that serves as an input for the pressure-swing adsorption and comes from the SMR is 4.9 H2/CO. Converting that into energy content, the hydrogen energy content of 1 MWh of syngas corresponds to 0.80708 MWh. According to literature the hydrogen recovery factor of a PSA is 90%. Therefore, the hydrogen content is multiplied with the recovery factor to get the hydrogen from the SMR.", "cost_inv_p": "value for SMR to hydrogen assumed with monetary conversion from €2015 to €2021. WGS and PSA together make up 28.3% of CAPEX according to Katebah et al. (2022). As we divide between SMR to syngas and syngas to hydrogen, both WGS and PSA are included in this step", "cost_fix_p": "assumed to be similar to SMR to hydrogen at 3.6%CAPEX which was multiplied with the column for the cost_inv_p", "lifetime": "literature valeus which were assumed to be similar to SMR to hydrogen", "wacc": ""}
comment: This process includes WGS and PSA
